title: Kinetics of bacterial potentiometric titrations : the effect of equilibration time on buffering capacity of Pantoea agglomerans suspensions
abstract:
Several recent studies have made use of continuous acid–base titration data to describe the surface chemistry of bacterial cells as a basis for accurately modelling metal adsorption to bacteria and other biomaterials of potential industrial importance. These studies do not share a common protocol; rather they titrate in different pH ranges and they use different stability criteria to define equilibration time during titration. In the present study we investigate the kinetics of bacterial titrations and test the effect they have on the derivation of functional group concentrations and acidity constants. We titrated suspensions of Pantoea agglomerans by varying the equilibration time between successive titrant additions until stability of 0.1 or 0.001 mV s−1 was attained. We show that under longer equilibration times, titration results are less reproducible and suspensions exhibit marginally higher buffering. Fluorescence images suggest that cell lysis is not responsible for these effects. Rather, high DOC values and titration reversibility hysterisis after long equilibration times suggest that variability in buffering is due to the presence of bacterial exudates, as demonstrated by titrating supernatants separated from suspensions of different equilibration times. It is recommended that an optimal equilibration time is always determined with variable stability control and preliminary reversibility titration experiments.\ud
\u

fullText:
Journal of Colloid and Interface Science, 359:481‐486. (Accepted version March 2011) 
 1
Kinetics of bacterial potentiometric titrations: the effect of equilibration time on 1 
buffering capacity of Pantoea agglomerans suspensions 2 
 3 
Leon Kapetasa,*, Bryne T. Ngwenyaa, Alan M. Macdonaldb and Stephen C. Elphicka. 4 
a School of Geosciences, Earth Subsurface Research Group, Grant Institute, 5 
University of Edinburgh, West Mains Road, Edinburgh EH9 3JW, United Kingdom 6 
b British Geological Survey, Murchison House, West Mains Road, Edinburgh EH9 7 
3LA, United Kingdom 8 
*Corresponding author. Tel: +44 (0) 1316508507, +30 6978651161, email: 9 
lekas11@gmail.com  10 
 11 
Abstract 12 
Several recent studies have made use of continuous acid-base titration data to describe 13 
the surface chemistry of bacterial cells as a basis for accurately modelling metal 14 
adsorption to bacteria and other biomaterials of potential industrial importance. These 15 
studies do not share a common protocol; rather they titrate in different pH ranges and 16 
they use different stability criteria to define equilibration time during titration. In the 17 
present study we investigate the kinetics of bacterial titrations and test the effect they 18 
have on the derivation of functional group concentrations and acidity constants. We 19 
titrated suspensions of Pantoea agglomerans by varying the equilibration time 20 
between successive titrant additions until stability of 0.1 or 0.001 mV s-1 was attained. 21 
We show that under longer equilibration times, titration results are less reproducible 22 
and suspensions exhibit marginally higher buffering. Fluorescence images suggest 23 
that cell lysis is not responsible for these effects. Rather, high DOC values and 24 
titration reversibility hysterisis after long equilibration times suggest that variability in 25 
Journal of Colloid and Interface Science, 359:481‐486. (Accepted version March 2011) 
 2
buffering is due to the presence of bacterial exudates, as demonstrated by titrating 26 
supernatants separated from suspensions of different equilibration times. It is 27 
recommended that an optimal equilibration time is always determined with variable 28 
stability control and preliminary reversibility titration experiments.  29 
 30 
Keywords: Bacterial titrations; stability criteria; exudate production 31 
 32 
1. Introduction 33 
Potentiometric titrations have become a standard methodology for characterising 34 
proton exchange between bacterial surfaces and their surrounding solutions. Acidity 35 
constants and concentrations of functional groups are derived using Surface 36 
Complexation (SC) modelling of titration results. These parameters are then used in 37 
SC models to predict metal adsorption by the cell surfaces [1-9]. A survey of 38 
experimental practice shows that there is no standard protocol adopted in all titration 39 
studies. For instance, the temperature of titration experiments might vary between 40 
studies despite recent evidence of the temperature dependence of titration results [10, 41 
11]. Similarly, there is no consensus regarding the pH range within which titrations 42 
should be carried out. In most studies suspension pH is dropped to a low value 43 
(between 2.4 and 4) by acidification or acid titration and then by base titration it is 44 
increased to approximately 10-11 [1, 2, 7, 12-22]. Fein et al. [23] carried out titrations 45 
to pH values as low as 2, since proton adsorption can occur at this low pH. However, 46 
in other studies it was preferred to titrate in both directions by separating the 47 
suspension into two equal volumes and starting titration from the immersion pH, for 48 
fear of denaturizing the cell membrane or promoting cell aggregation under extreme 49 
pH conditions [3, 6]. Borrok et al. [24] suggested that suspension pH values close to 3 50 
Journal of Colloid and Interface Science, 359:481‐486. (Accepted version March 2011) 
 3
can cause cell damage, indicated by elevated DOC values at this pH range. Similarly, 51 
for pH above 10 significant cell lysis can occur and may interfere with the buffering 52 
measurements [23]. 53 
 54 
Another significant issue is the stability criterion chosen to estimate equilibration time 55 
for continuous titrations.  In most studies the equilibration time is controlled by the 56 
stability criterion of 0.1 mV s-1 [2-4, 8, 14, 16, 17, 20, 25]. In a few studies the 57 
stability criterion is set at 0.01 mV s-1 [7, 23], while in others it is more strict with 58 
values of 0.1 and 0.15 mV min-1 (0.0017  and 0.0025 mV s-1) [18, 19]. Other studies 59 
use pH units when reporting stability criteria at 0.001 pH s-1, approximately 60 
equivalent to 0.06 mV s-1 [1, 26]. Alternatively, a few studies have dealt with this 61 
problem by conducting discontinuous titrations in limited residence time reactors [27, 62 
28]. This approach has been adapted from mineral surface charge studies [29-31]. 63 
Nevertheless, most studies use the traditional continuous titration approach, which is 64 
the focus of this study. 65 
 66 
As yet, there has been no study that has rigorously investigated the amount of time 67 
required to reach equilibrium during bacterial titrations, i.e. investigate if the reaction 68 
of the surface with the acid/base proceeds after the stability criterion is met.  Duc et al. 69 
[32] used oxide mineral surfaces to examine the effect of the acid-base titration speed 70 
on the pH measurements and on the surface charge calculation. They found that when 71 
the titration speed was increased, the measured pH value for the same added volume 72 
of acid increased. They differentiated between “fast” step reactions, attributed to the 73 
surface, and “slow” step reactions during titrations. By analogy, our study examines 74 
the effect that titration speed can have on bacterial surface proton exchange. Our 75 
Journal of Colloid and Interface Science, 359:481‐486. (Accepted version March 2011) 
 4
hypothesis tests whether longer equilibration times will lead to further acid/base 76 
consumption due to proton surface adsorption and/or intracellular 77 
diffusion/consumption. Alternatively, longer times could cause cell lysis and/or the 78 
production of exudates which might lead to higher buffering capacity than expected 79 
by the surface chemistry alone. We use a combination of titration results using 80 
different titration speeds, DOC measurements, titration reversibility and cell viability 81 
examination to investigate these hypotheses. 82 
 83 
84 
Journal of Colloid and Interface Science, 359:481‐486. (Accepted version March 2011) 
 5
2. Materials and Methods 85 
2.1. Bacterial potentiometric titrations 86 
Fresh batches of Pantoea agglomerans (also known as Enterobacter agglomerans 87 
[33]) cells were cultured and titrated after the method of Tourney et al. [21]. 88 
Potentiometric titrations were carried out on fresh cell pellets suspended in 50 mL 89 
0.01M NaClO4 background electrolyte. Before titration, cell pellets were washed three 90 
additional times in NaClO4 electrolyte of the same concentration used in the titration 91 
experiments. Also, the pH of the cell suspension was adjusted to approximately 4 by 92 
adding a known amount of standard 0.5 M HNO3 solution. The pH was not reduced 93 
further in order to avoid cell lysis [24] and “acid shock” to the cells [34]. 94 
 95 
Titrations were carried out between pH values 4 and 10 in dynamic mode with a 96 
DL53 Mettler Toledo automatic titrator. Using this automated setting the volume of 97 
the successive aliquots of titrant standard 0.5 M NaOH added to the suspension was 98 
adjustable – it was increased when change of pH was small and it was reduced when 99 
pH shift was large. Titrations were carried out using two different stability criteria: 0.1 100 
and 0.001 pH min-1 (equivalent to 0.1 and 0.001 mV s-1), set as 0.1 mV in 1 s and 0.06 101 
mV in 60 s respectively (a criterion of less than 0.06 mV should not be used due to 102 
meter precision limitations). The two stability criteria were chosen simply to represent 103 
the two extremes commonly used in the literature, as reviewed above. For the short 104 
equilibration time, a minimum and maximum equilibration time was set at 2 and 5 105 
minutes respectively, while for the long equilibration time the minimum and 106 
maximum time was set at 2 and 12 minutes respectively. The upper time limit was set 107 
to allow the titration to proceed in case of continuous buffering of the base. It also 108 
guaranteed that the titrations would be completed within 4 hours, thus avoiding the 109 
Journal of Colloid and Interface Science, 359:481‐486. (Accepted version March 2011) 
 6
possibility of cell starvation leading to cell death [35]. Reversibility titrations were 110 
also conducted at the two equilibration times. Down-pH titrations were carried out 111 
using standard 0.5 M HNO3 titrant. 112 
 113 
2.2. Titration data modelling 114 
Surface complexation modelling of titration data was carried out using the 115 
optimization program FITEQL 4.0 [36]. Titration data were plotted in terms of molar 116 
concentration of protons exchanged by the cell surface per gram of  biomass 117 
according to Fein et al. [23]: 118 
bexch mHOHCbCaH /])[][(][
              (1) 119 
where Ca and Cb are the concentrations of acid and base (mol L-1) for each titration 120 
step, [OH-] and [H+] (mol L-1) are the equilibrium concentrations of OH- and H+ at 121 
equilibrium and mb is the dry biomass concentration (g L-1). Hence, [H+]exch has units 122 
of mol g-1. Due to uncertainties with determining the surface potential [23], a non 123 
electrostatic model was chosen to derive the concentrations and acidity constants of 124 
the functional groups that exchange protons. We describe their deprotonation using a 125 
number of monoprotic discrete acids according to Borrok and Fein [37]: 126 
  HARAHR     (2) 127 
where R denotes the bacterium where the functional group type, A, is attached. R-A- 128 
and R-AH represent deprotonated and protonated sites of the functional group 129 
respectively. Acidity constants Ki (i= 1, 2, 3…) are calculated using the following 130 
expression: 131 
][
]][[
AHR
HARKi 


    (3) 132 
Journal of Colloid and Interface Science, 359:481‐486. (Accepted version March 2011) 
 7
where brackets represent the concentrations of the sites at equilibrium and [H+] the 133 
activity of protons in solution. Cell surfaces are negatively charged even at low pH 134 
conditions [23]. Hence, titration data were corrected to account for initial protonation 135 
state [21, 23, 38, 39]. This correction vertically shifts the titration curves closer to the 136 
isoelectric point of most bacteria as determined by electrophoretic mobility 137 
measurements [22, 23, 40]. Models with varying number of functional group types 138 
were tested and the quality of fit criterion V(Y) of FITEQL 4.0 was used to select the 139 
most suitable model [8]. A value of V(Y) lower than 20 suggests a good model fit. 140 
 141 
2.3. Dissolved organic carbon (DOC) measurements 142 
DOC samples were taken from bacterial suspensions. The sample preparation and 143 
analysis technique is detailed in Tourney et al. [41]. Briefly, samples were filtered 144 
into ashed glass vials using a 0.22 μm cellulose acetate membrane syringe filters. 145 
Samples were then frozen until DOC analysis was carried out with a Shimadzu 6000 146 
TOC/TDN analyser. The analyser incorporates a high temperature catalytic oxidation 147 
and non-dispersive infrared detector. External calibration standards prepared from a 148 
stock solution of 1 g L-1 potassium hydrogen phthalate were run. Blank samples were 149 
measured to correct sample DOC concentrations. The detection limit of the instrument 150 
is 24 μg L-1, while the observed analytical precision was better than 2% in terms of 151 
relative standard deviation.   152 
 153 
2.4. Fluorescence Microscopy 154 
Live/dead bacteria viability tests were carried out on bacterial suspension samples 155 
taken at different pH values. Sample volumes of 1 mL were taken from the titration 156 
suspension and centrifuged for 5 minutes in ependorf microtubes. Cells were then 157 
Journal of Colloid and Interface Science, 359:481‐486. (Accepted version March 2011) 
 8
washed twice in 0.14 M NaCl solution and resuspended in 1 mL of 0.14 M NaCl. The 158 
resulting suspension was stained with 3 μL of a 50:50 mixture containing SYTO 9 159 
green-fluorescent nucleic acid stain and Propidium Iodide red-fluorescent nucleic acid 160 
stain. The suspension was incubated according to the manufacturer’s protocol [42] 161 
and cells were observed and photographed using a Zeiss Axioplan 2 microscope using 162 
FITC filter with excitation 485/20, emission 525/30 and the Texas Red filter with 163 
excitation 560/25, emission 607/36. A Photometrics Coolsnap HQ camera was used 164 
and all hardware was controlled by Metamorph 7.5. Images of live/dead bacteria for 165 
every slide were finally combined using ImageJ (National Institute of Health, USA). 166 
Bacterial counts were carried out using CellC software for quantification of labelled 167 
bacteria by automated image analysis [43]. This counting technique has a nominal 2% 168 
error. Comparisons between manual and CellC counts provided a 5% error in 169 
estimates, which is consistent with the results of Gorman-Lewis [44].  170 
 171 
172 
Journal of Colloid and Interface Science, 359:481‐486. (Accepted version March 2011) 
 9
3. Results 173 
3.1. Titrations at varying equilibration times 174 
Titrations were carried out on cell suspensions of 6, 9 and 12 g L-1 dry mass under 175 
both stability criteria. As can be seen in figure 1a, titrations are well reproduced when 176 
fast equilibration is selected (low stability). On the other hand, figure 1b shows that 177 
high stability leads to larger variation in titration results. Moreover, the titration curve 178 
for the 12 g L-1 reveals notably higher buffering capacity than the titration data of 179 
figure 1a. Titration of the 12 g L-1 suspension at 0.001 pH min-1 exhibits higher 180 
buffering than the two titrations carried out with the same stability criterion, but with 181 
less biomass. Also, the 9 g L-1 at 0.001 pH min-1 data show a marginally higher 182 
buffering capacity than the 6 g L-1 at 0.001 pH min-1 data, though this difference is 183 
within experimental error.  184 
 185 
Two cell suspensions of 12 g L-1 were titrated at 0.1 and 0.001 pH min-1 and their 186 
supernatants were titrated under the same criteria respectively. Figure 1c shows the 187 
negligible buffering capacity of a bacteria-free electrolyte solution and compares the 188 
buffering of the titrated supernatant suspensions. The supernatant titrated at 0.001 pH 189 
min-1 shows 2.5 times greater buffering than the one titrated at 0.1 pH min-1. Hence, it 190 
is suggested that DOC is present in the supernatant and has a variable contribution to 191 
buffering depending on the stability criterion used. The concentration of exchanged 192 
protons shown in figure 1c is approximated by the concentration of base added to the 193 
supernatant solution. This approximation is required since the amount of base and 194 
acid added during the bacterial titration is not all transferred to the supernatant 195 
solution (cells had to be centrifuged and removed) and hence can not be calculated. 196 
Nonetheless, this practically does not affect the calculation of the buffering capacity 197 
Journal of Colloid and Interface Science, 359:481‐486. (Accepted version March 2011) 
 10
of the supernatant, as it is base concentration that dominates buffering, i.e. the 198 
difference in Hexch between pH 4 and 10 is practically equal to the difference in Cb for 199 
the same pH range. Note that correcting bacterial titrations for supernatant buffering 200 
does not necessarily improve the quality of the titration results. This is because DOC 201 
generated at high pH was not present for the entire duration of the bacterial titration, 202 
i.e. no correction is required for the initial times. 203 
 204 
Figure 1. Titration curves carried out using the (a) 0.1 pH min-1 and (b) 0.001 pH min-205 
1 stability criteria, shown in the top and middle figure respectively. Results have been 206 
normalised by dry mass and corrected for initial protonation state. The titration curve 207 
of 12 g L-1 carried out under low stability is plotted in figure 1b to allow comparisons 208 
of the curve’s shapes and of their buffering capacity. The normalised buffering 209 
capacity of electrolyte and supernatant solutions are shown in the bottom figure (c).  210 
 211 
The 0.1 pH min-1 stability criterion was met for all bacterial titration points within the 212 
time limits set by the experimental protocol. The 0.001 pH min-1 stability criterion 213 
was met in the beginning of the titration until approximately pH 5.5-6. Above this pH 214 
value the time required for equilibration increased and the upper limit of 12 minutes 215 
was met before proceeding to new titrant addition, i.e. “equilibrium” was many times 216 
not attained under 0.001 pH min-1 criterion at pH values greater than 6. The fact that 217 
equilibrium was not attained, also points to the production of DOC during the time 218 
course of the titration, as will be shown in section 3.2. DOC in turn leads to the 219 
displacement of the titration curves shown in figure 1b.  220 
 221 
A quantitative understanding of the differences between the bacterial titration curves 222 
is provided by comparing the acidity constants and concentrations of the functional 223 
Journal of Colloid and Interface Science, 359:481‐486. (Accepted version March 2011) 
 11
groups of the surface. Table 1a shows the results of the 4 site non electrostatic model 224 
which best described the titration curves. The average values of the acidity constants 225 
for both stability criteria are consistent with literature values of studies which made 226 
use of a four site non electrostatic model [16, 17, 21, 23, 38]. However, pK1 is higher 227 
than those found in literature because titrations did not cover the low pH range. This 228 
is due to a limitation of the modelling approach, which does not effectively 229 
extrapolate results outside or near the edge of the pH range of the dataset [45]. There 230 
is an apparent shift to higher pK values associated with higher uncertainties when the 231 
stability criterion of 0.001 pH min-1 is used. The buffering capacity in the pH 4-10 232 
range is comparable to that of gram negative Pseudomonas putida [46], however is an 233 
order of magnitude lower than that of Pseudomonas aureofaciens [40]. Moreover, 234 
there is an average increase in total buffering capacity by almost 10-4 mol g-1 when 235 
allowing longer equilibration. The difference in DOC buffering between the two 236 
supernatant titration curves (figure 1c) is large enough to account for this increase. 237 
The increase in buffering due to the presence of DOC is more notable at high biomass 238 
titrations because they last longer (more base consumed). Thus they allow more time 239 
for DOC production.  Moreover, the calculated functional group concentrations carry 240 
high uncertainties in both cases, albeit with higher uncertainties in the 0.001 pH min-1 241 
titrations.  242 
 243 
 244 
 245 
 246 
 247 
 248 
Journal of Colloid and Interface Science, 359:481‐486. (Accepted version March 2011) 
 12

 249 
Parameter pK1 pK2 pK3 pK4 T(total) 
p-value 0.30 0.88 0.17 0.03 0.36 
 250 
Table 1. Values of acidity constants and site concentrations under the 0.1 pH min-1 251 
and 0.001 pH min-1 stability criteria (top). Results are averages of the titration curves 252 
shown in Figure 1. The p-values in table 1 (bottom), derived from student’s t-test, 253 
examine statistical differences between estimated parameters shown in table 1 (top). 254 
 255 
Titration modelling results for 0.1 and 0.001 pH min-1 stability criteria were analysed 256 
with a t-test to examine whether they are statistically different. An F-test on the 257 
modelled values (table 1 top) suggested that they possibly have statistically different 258 
variances. Therefore, the Welch’s t-test was applied, which is a specific solution of 259 
the Student’s t-test for samples with different variances [47]. Table 1 (bottom) shows 260 
the results of the t-test in terms of the probability that the mean values under study are 261 
statistically similar. At 95% confidence interval, only the pK4 values are statistically 262 
different between the two experimental protocols. It is apparent in figure 1b that 263 
deviation of titration curves carried out under different stability criteria takes place at 264 
the high pH range. Not surprisingly, this would be reflected in the values of pK4 265 
and/or T4. Individual differences in site concentrations are not examined with the t-266 
test since their values carry high uncertainties. Rather, it was preferred to compare the 267 
Journal of Colloid and Interface Science, 359:481‐486. (Accepted version March 2011) 
 13
total site concentrations between the two experimental protocols. As can be seen in 268 
table 1 (bottom), the difference in T(total) was not significant.  269 
 270 
3.2. DOC results 271 
Dissolved organic carbon (DOC) samples were taken at the initial pH~6.2 conditions 272 
of the suspension, at near pH 4 after the acidification step and at pH~10 conditions 273 
after the termination of the base titration. This was done for 9 g L-1 titration 274 
suspensions at both fast and slow titration rates. At the fast titration rate, DOC slightly 275 
increased after the acidification of the sample from 2.44 mg L-1 at immersion pH 276 
conditions (pH~6.2) to 4.62 mg L-1 at pH~4. After the titration of the sample with 277 
base, DOC was measured again and was found equal to 4.81 mg L-1 (pH~10). At the 278 
slow titration rate, DOC was initially measured at 1.82 mg L-1 (pH~ 6.2). After the 279 
sample was acidified to pH~4, DOC increased to 3.50 mg L-1. DOC increased 280 
significantly to 22.80 mg L-1 after the suspension was slowly titrated with base to 281 
pH~10. It has been shown that DOC levels in P. agglomerans suspensions clearly 282 
increase with time, particularly at higher pH conditions [48]. Pokrovsky et al. also 283 
found that levels of DOC increased during the course of automatic titrations of 284 
cyanobacteria Gloeocapsa sp., which did not allow the quantification of surface 285 
proton adsorption with this method  [28]. The increase in DOC can be attributed either 286 
to the lysis product of a portion of the titrated cells or to the release of exudates [48]. 287 
Claessens et al. reported an increase in base neutralisation at pH above 8 during static 288 
experiments and suggested that this was related to a metabolic response of Shewanella 289 
putrefaciens cells releasing organic compounds [13]. On the other hand, Wightman et 290 
al. showed that DOC does not contribute to proton buffering of B. subtilis surface 291 
titrations [49]. In this case, the production of DOC likely explains the variability in 292 
Journal of Colloid and Interface Science, 359:481‐486. (Accepted version March 2011) 
 14
the bacterial titration results between figure 1a and 1b, and is responsible for the 293 
proton buffering by the supernatants. The origin of the DOC measured in suspension 294 
at high pH after the long titrations (0.001 pH min-1) is investigated below by 295 
examining viability of the cells in suspension.   296 
 297 
3.3. Cell viability 298 
Fluorescence images of cells used in titrations were taken in order to understand the 299 
effect that acidic and basic conditions or prolonged titrations can have on cell viability. 300 
Live and Dead cell counts were carried out for suspensions before acidification, after 301 
acidification and after completion of the base titration of a 9 g L-1 suspension at 0.001 302 
pH min-1. Glass slides were spotted with suspensions prepared from samples at initial 303 
pH~6.2, pH~4 and pH~10. Five images were taken per slide and more than 1000 cells 304 
were counted for every slide in order to obtain a representative idea of cell viability. 305 
Proportion of live/dead cells was essentially the same at immersion pH~6.2 (88% 306 
Live, 12% Dead), at pH~4 (86% Live, 14% Dead) after acidification, and at pH~10 307 
(85% Live, 15% Dead) after titrating with base at 0.001 pH min-1. Percentage 308 
differences are within error associated with the experimental technique and counting 309 
method. Results of this semi-quantitative analysis suggest that cell lysis does not take 310 
place during the prolonged duration of the titration carried out within the 4-10 pH 311 
range using the 0.001 pH min-1 criterion. Since cell lysis is not the source of DOC, we 312 
suggest exudate production as the source. 313 
 314 
3.4. Reversibility of titrations 315 
The presence of higher DOC concentration increases proton buffering, but might also 316 
affect the reversibility of titrations. Hence we decided to investigate this possibility. 317 
Journal of Colloid and Interface Science, 359:481‐486. (Accepted version March 2011) 
 15
Reversibility of titrations on 9 g L-1 bacterial suspensions was tested at both fast and 318 
low equilibration speed to investigate the potential effect of DOC. Figure 2 presents 319 
the acid and base titration curve results for both criteria. Results were corrected for 320 
initial protonation state assuming a 3 site non electrostatic model, as acid titrations did 321 
not converge under a 4 site model due to significant hysterisis. This difference does 322 
not affect buffering capacity of the titrations. While some reversibility hysterisis was 323 
exhibited during fast equilibration (low stability), the slow equilibration procedure 324 
(high stability) resulted in significant hysterisis, more pronounced at high pH where 325 
high DOC (exudates) production has been demonstrated. Bacterial titration 326 
irreversibility has been observed for other species during short equilibration times 327 
[13], although most studies have not shown such behaviour at either high [50] or low 328 
stability [2, 15, 25, 49, 51]. Further investigation is required to test whether such 329 
behaviour may be strain-dependent in terms of exudates production. Moreover, higher 330 
buffering was confirmed in the base titration with longer equilibration time (figure 2). 331 
Both observations suggest that a portion of the buffering during long equilibration 332 
times is not related to the exchange of protons from the bacterial surface. Instead, an 333 
interaction between protons and released DOC is believed to be taking place. The 334 
localisation of hysterisis to high pH suggests that the exudates contain primarily high 335 
pKa functional groups which do not contribute to solution phase proton buffering at 336 
low pH. This suggestion is in agreement with the supernatant titration results, which 337 
show greater proton buffering at high pH and convergence of curves from different 338 
titration speeds at low pH. 339 
 340 
Figure 2. Reversibility of acid-base titrations of 9 g L-1 dry weight cell suspensions 341 
equilibrated using 0.1 pH min-1 (closed symbols) and 0.001 pH min-1 (open symbols) 342 
Journal of Colloid and Interface Science, 359:481‐486. (Accepted version March 2011) 
 16
stability criteria. Circle and squares represent base and acid titration data respectively. 343 
Results were normalised by dry weight to represent the proton exchange capacity per 344 
gram biomass dry weight. 345 
 346 
347 
Journal of Colloid and Interface Science, 359:481‐486. (Accepted version March 2011) 
 17
4. Discussion and Conclusions  348 
When the stability criterion is set lower at 0.001 pH min-1 to allow more time for 349 
equilibration, reproducibility of titrations is influenced adversely. The time limit for 350 
equilibration (12 min) had to be invoked as equilibrium was not attained. High 351 
stability is not suitable for this biomaterial due to inherent uncertainties related to its 352 
metabolic activity. The total site concentration of the fast titrations is lower than the 353 
total concentration of the slower titrations. However, as was shown this difference is 354 
not statistically significant. This is because the exudates produced by these bacteria 355 
have low buffering capacity (as demonstrated by titration of supernatants), such that 356 
overall buffering remains dominated by the cell surface. Based on reversibility 357 
experiments, exudates contribute to total buffering primarily at high pH with 358 
maximum hysterisis around pK3/pK4 sites. This was also confirmed by titrating the 359 
supernatant of cell suspensions separately. Furthermore, significant differences at a 360 
95% confidence interval are observed only in the values of pK4. This is anticipated 361 
since the variability of deprotonation between titrations with different stability criteria 362 
is more notable at the high pH range (~8-10). 363 
 364 
The titration of the supernatants and the DOC measurements give an insight into the 365 
possible origin of the observed variability between titrations at varying equilibration 366 
times. When the duration of the titrations is increased, the amount of DOC in the 367 
system increases significantly. The higher DOC values measured in our study suggest 368 
that bacteria are metabolically releasing exudates. This inference is supported by the 369 
fact that cell integrity between pH 4 and 10 is maintained in our experiments, since no 370 
cell lysis takes place as shown by fluorescent imaging. The differences in cell 371 
viability between initial, high and low pH are only marginal and within the precision 372 
Journal of Colloid and Interface Science, 359:481‐486. (Accepted version March 2011) 
 18
of the method. Moreover, the duration of the experiments is sufficiently short to 373 
exclude the possibility of cell starvation and death. 374 
 375 
Exudates account for the slight increase in buffering capacity, but also for the lack of 376 
reproducibility between titrations carried out with the high stability criteria. As the 377 
exudates react with the titrating acid/base added, the buffering observed cannot be 378 
entirely attributed to the consumption of titrant by the cell surface. The larger 379 
reversibility hysterisis noticed at 0.001 pH min-1 accompanied by increase DOC 380 
values provides additional evidence to this.  381 
 382 
We have tested whether increasing equilibration time during titration increases the 383 
exchange of protons with the surface. Our results suggest it is preferable to use fast 384 
equilibrium stability criteria, so that most of the apparent buffering capacity can be 385 
attributed to the surface reactions. However, this result is not necessarily transferable. 386 
Future studies should individually (i) check for the buffering contribution of the 387 
supernatant and (ii) examine the reversibility of titrations of each bacterial species 388 
under each culture and titration protocol, as titrations might be reversible over a short 389 
time scales but not over long periods [15]. It was shown that the selection of stability 390 
criterion depends on the demonstration of reversibility; nevertheless, reversibility was 391 
not attained during this study under neither stability criteria.  392 
 393 
Strictly, the observed irreversibility under both criteria renders problematic the use of 394 
a thermodynamic approach on the titration curves, although the low contribution to 395 
buffering by exudates means that the differences are not statistically significant and 396 
thus only affect precision. This effect became apparent in the quality of surface 397 
Journal of Colloid and Interface Science, 359:481‐486. (Accepted version March 2011) 
 19
complexation modelling results which degraded due to the presence of non cell 398 
surface related buffering. This has implications for determining surface sites for 399 
bacteria that shed DOC to the electrolyte, e.g. EPS-producing ones [21]. Finally, we 400 
suggest that small differences in site densities and pKa values reported in bacterial 401 
titration studies can, in some situations, be an artefact of different equilibration times. 402
